Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Assembling the Echinoderm Tree of Life
Award.AbstractNarration:
Echinoderms include familiar animals such as starfishes, sea urchins, and a wide array of extinct forms stretching back to the Cambrian Period, circa 500 million years ago. Echinoderms share a common ancestor with backboned animals and thus provide a crucial link to understanding a huge portion of the entire tree of life as well as the history of our species. This project, the Echinoderm Tree of Life Project, will resolve the phylogenetic placement of Echinoderms within the tree of life and clarify important unresolved relationships among major echinoderm lineages using data from genetic sequencing and anatomy.

Echinoderms are fascinating, and their unique features, such as mutable ligaments and novel means of detecting light, have biomedical engineering applications. Because research on such marine animals and their adaptations is naturally attractive to young people, excellent students are expected to be recruited and the importance of science will be communicated to a broad audience. Long-term impacts, embodied by scientific publications, textbooks, anatomical and genomic data, and extensive pages in the Tree of Life and Encyclopedia of Life web projects, will provide resources to researchers and educators. Outreach will include videos and broadcasts about marine exploration and applications of fundamental biological research across the biomedical sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As one of four paleontologists on a team of 12 P.I.s and Co-P.I.s, including eight biologists, my research role was to help assemble and interpret the fossil record of stemmed echinoderms. This was part of the initial goal “To develop an echinoderm phylogeny based on formulating homologous morphological characters among all fossil and extant groups, despite diverse anatomical nomenclature.”  Stemmed, or attached, echinoderms (pelmatozoans) consist of the extinct blastozoans and the crinoids, which include both extinct and living groups.  Crinoids are the most primitive of the five classes of living echinoderms.  The other classes are the asteroids, ophiuroids, echinoids, and holothurians, which are all non-attached and mobile (eleutherozoans).  Thus, understanding the evolutionary history of crinoids is critical for assembling the branching order near the base of the echinoderm tree of life for both living and fossil echinoderms, all of which are strictly marine animals.

Stemmed echinoderms, represented by several extinct classes of blastozoans, are among the earliest echinoderms, first appearing in the Cambrian Period, around 520 million years ago.  Crinoids first appeared in the next younger Ordovician Period, around 480 million years ago.  The team of paleontologists focused their initial efforts on searching for possible morphological characters in common between blastozoans and early crinoids.  Identifying common morphological characters, or homologies, from shared common ancestors is how branching order (phylogeny) is recognized in the tree of life for fossil groups because DNA is not available for study.

The team of paleontologists had great success in recognizing a large number of homologies found in the oral regions of crinoids, blastozoans, and also edrioasteroids, which are immobile, non-stemmed echinoderms presumably related to blastozoans.  This work was published as a major paper in PLOS ONE (2013, e77989).  The recognition of a broad suite of characters defined homologies shared by edrioasteroids and various blastozoans, and homologies between other blastozoans and crinoids.  This supported the conclusion that blastozoans were an evolutionary bridge between the most primitive edrioasteroids and crinoids.  Thus, the common ancestor for all stemmed echinoderms must be within the earliest edrioasteroids (or their close relatives), which are among the oldest known pentaradial echinoderms from the middle Cambrian, which is significant because all living echinoderms are pentaradial.  The results of this work will have important implications in understanding how living eleutherozoans are related to fossil echinoderms more primitive than crinoids as there is no evidence that living crinoids are closely related to the other classes of living echinoderms.

Building on the work published in PLOS ONE, the homologies discovered between blastozoans and crinoids were used to investigate the branching order of the main groups of Ordovician crinoids, which represent the oldest known crinoids.  This allowed recognition of the previously unknown branching order in recognized lineages of Paleozoic crinoids using computer-aided phylogenetic methods.  The results were published as a major paper in PALAEONTOLOGY (2015, 58:937-952).  Comparing the oral region characters from six widely divergent taxa of blastozoans (the outgroup) resulted in highly-resolved trees for various groupings of crinoids.  The branching order for evolutionary origins in crinoids was found to be:  Camerata, Protocrinoida, and Cladida.  The Cladida then gave rise separately to the Hybocrinida and Disparida, indicating that the Cladida is a paraphyletic group.  The Cladida also contains the ancestors of the living crinoids, the Articulata.  Work is continuing on the details of the Crinoidea tree of life above the Ordovician, but the branching order of the major lineages is now well constrained as they all have recognized roots in the Ordovician.

Another application of recognizing oral region homologies in pelmatozoans was to investigate the constructional pathways of oral surface coverings (tegmens) in both crinoids and blastozoans during their entire evolutionary history.  This led to a third major paper that was published in the JOURNAL OF PALEONTOLOGY (2016, 90:689-720).  This work demonstrated the repetitive evolutionary origin of plated structures within groups, and the independent origins between groups, to protect the mouth and surrounding area in these animals from predators and parasites.  Recognizing these various constructional pathways is important for recognizing homologous characters, vs. homoplastic characters (convergent), that aid in the development of phylogenetic hypotheses (e.g., evolutionary trees).

In summary, the results from this project for the larger collaborative effort are significant in demonstrating the relationships of living crinoids to fossil crinoids and their fossil relatives, the blastozoans and edrioasteroids.  This will greatly aid in the future assembly of the Echinoderm Tree of Life incorporating morphological data from the fossil record with both morphological and genomic data from living echinoderms.
